Let C\mathcal{C}C be a 2-category.
Let XXX be an object in C\mathcal{C}C.

I propose the following "Internal bicategory of spans in XXX".

The object of spans in XXX, if it exists, is the 2-limit of the diagram X←X→XX\leftarrow X \rightarrow XX←X→X. It is equipped with a certain span d←u→cd\leftarrow u\rightarrow cd←u→c in the hom-category C(S(X),X)\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{S}(X),X)C(S(X),X), which is universal among spans in C(Y,X)\mathcal{C}(Y,X)C(Y,X) for variable YYY.
Say that XXX has pullbacks if C(Y,X)\mathcal{C}(Y,X)C(Y,X) has pullbacks for all YYY and they are preserved under precomposition with 1-cells Y′→YY'\to YY′→Y.
I claim that if XXX has pullbacks, then there is a pseudocategory internal to C\mathcal{C}C whose objects are XXX and whose arrows are S(X)\mathcal{S}(X)S(X), composition is as it is in the bicategory of spans.

Checking the details on this is a pain to do and a pain to write down (pentagon identity will be annoying) so i'd like a reference. Does anyone know of this? Is this a known construction?
Also acceptable is a slick construction of this that allows me to say "the pentagon identity holds because this is a special case of this other thing where the pentagon identity is known to hold"

the 2-limit of the diagram X←X→XX\leftarrow X\to XX←X→X

Do you mean the lax limit?
It should also be the power (= cotensor) of XXX by the "walking span" category (⋅←⋅→⋅)(\cdot \leftarrow \cdot \to \cdot)(⋅←⋅→⋅).

For a slick construction, the first thing that occurs to me is that Span\rm SpanSpan is a 2-functor PB→Dbl\rm PB \to DblPB→Dbl from the 2-category of categories with pullbacks to the 2-category of double categories. Now the assumption that X∈CX\in \mathcal{C}X∈C has pullbacks means that its representable functor Cop→Cat\mathcal{C}^{\rm op} \to \rm CatCop→Cat actually lands in PB\rm PBPB. Composing we get Cop→PB→Dbl\mathcal{C}^{\rm op} \to \rm PB \to DblCop→PB→Dbl. The assumption that the object of spans exists means that the composite of this functor with both the "category of objects" and the "category of morphisms" functors Dbl→Cat\rm Dbl\to CatDbl→Cat are representable. So now the Yoneda lemma should imply that the associativity and coherence etc. in Dbl\rm DblDbl can equivalently be expressed internally in C\mathcal{C}C.

Mike Shulman said:

the 2-limit of the diagram X←X→XX\leftarrow X\to XX←X→X

Do you mean the lax limit?

I don't know what the terminology is. I mean it represents the 2-functor Cop→Cat\mathcal{C}^{\rm op}\to \mathbf{Cat}Cop→Cat sending YYY to the category of spans in C(Y,X)\mathcal{C}(Y,X)C(Y,X).
I also think the yoneda lemma is the way to go here but i don't quite follow you with how the double category structure comes into it.
The associativity and coherence you're talking about are internal to the double categories, not between them, right?

ohh I might see what you're saying. It sounds like you're saying something like, try and generalize the theorem that
if Hom(−,X)Hom(-,X)Hom(−,X) is valued in the category of groups rather than just sets, then by Yoneda XXX must be a group obje (assuming C has the Cartesian products necessary to form X×XX\times XX×X).
Similarly here if Hom(−,C)Hom(-, C)Hom(−,C) is valued in double categories, CCC must itself be a double category somehow.

Like, somehow there's some slightly more general finite limit theory version of Yoneda at play?
Handwavy definition because it's slightly difficult to phrase it right:
A 2-categorical finite limit theory consists of a finite number of 0-cells X1,…,XnX_1,\dots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ and a finite number of 1-cells g1,…,gmg_1,\dots, g_mg1​,…,gm​ and 2-cells κ1,…,κs\kappa_1,\dots, \kappa_sκ1​,…,κs​ where the domain and codomain of gk+1g_{k+1}gk+1​ are permitted to be, inductively, any (formal) finite lax limit built from the X1,…,XnX_1,\dots,X_nX1​,…,Xn​ and g1,…,gkg_1,\dots, g_kg1​,…,gk​.

One should have a 2-category of models of this theory in any 2-category, and lax 2-functors induce functors between the associated 2-categories of models. (In particular, pseudocategories are supposed to be models of a particular "algebraic theory" in this sense.)

Now let C\mathcal{C}C be a 2-category, and say we have a functor AAA from Cop\mathcal{C}^{\rm op}Cop into the category of models of a finite lax limit theory. AAA can always be viewed, equivalently, as a single model of the theory in the functor category [Cop,Cat][\mathcal{C}^{\rm op},\mathbf{Cat}][Cop,Cat]. Now we claim that if each object in the diagram AAA is representable, then by Yoneda all 1 and 2 cells in the model are also representable, and this lifts to a model of the theory in C\mathcal{C}C.

It's important here that Yoneda preserves finite limits. Does 2-categorical Yoneda preserve finite lax limits? Is that important here?

Yes, that's the right idea, except that in the general stuff about finite 2-limit theories you don't ever want to use the word "lax". Lax has a specific meaning, it refers to having noninvertible mediating 2-cells.

For instance, a lax functor doesn't preserve composition even up to isomorphism, it just has specified 2-cells F(g)∘F(f)⇒F(g∘f)F(g) \circ F(f) \Rightarrow F(g\circ f)F(g)∘F(f)⇒F(g∘f) satisfying coherence laws. Lax functors are useful for some things, but when treating 2-categories as categorifications of 1-categories you almost never want to talk about lax functors as they rarely preserve anything interesting and aren't even invariant under equivalence. Instead you want either strict 2-functors, which preserve composition strictly, or pseudo 2-functors, which preserve it up to isomorphism -- they are lax functors whose comparison 2-cells are invertible.

A lax limit, on the other hand, is more useful, but is only a special case of the general notion of weighted 2-limit. The lax limit of a diagram DDD is a universal object LLL equipped with projections px:L→Dxp_x : L \to D xpx​:L→Dx along with for every f:x→yf:x\to yf:x→y a 2-cell Df∘px⇒pyD f \circ p_x \Rightarrow p_yDf∘px​⇒py​, satisfying coherence laws. If DDD is the diagram X←X→XX \leftarrow X \to XX←X→X, you can see that this is the "object of spans" in XXX. Whereas the strict 2-limit of this diagram (which has equalities Df∘px=pyD f \circ p_x = p_yDf∘px​=py​) would be isomorphic to XXX, and the pseudo 2-limit would be equivalent to XXX. But there is a general notion of weighted 2-limit which includes strict ones, pseudo ones, and lax ones, as well as other things, and (as in enriched category theory more generally) that's what one would use when formulating a notion of finite-limit theory.
